abstract.text: At the eve of the second LHC data taking run, some of the most recent results obtained by the LHCb collaboration with Run I data are reviewed.
Improved measurements on CP violation, unitary triangle and mixing parameters are shown.
Recent progress on physics in the forward region is illustrated by examples picked up in the electroweak physics and beyond Standard Model searches.

body_text.text: Introduction
The LHCb research programme is principally focused on using heavy flavour decays to probe the intervention of New Physics through the involvement of heavy new particles in loop decays.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: For this purpose, neutral B 0 q (q = d, s) meson oscillations, mediated by box diagrams, and rare decays, proceeding through loop flavour changing neutral currents, come as natural grounds to seek for any deviation from Standard Model-based predictions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Spectroscopy of heavyflavoured hadrons is also considered along these research lines.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Beside this, the low transverse momentum threshold, the excellent vertex reconstruction, and the peculiar forward geometry of the LHCb detector allows for complementary studies to what is performed with ATLAS or CMS detectors, on areas such as QCD and Electroweak physics, as well as searches for displaced vertices of heavy decaying particles.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Most of the analyses are based on the full Run I (years 2011 and 2012) data sample, representing 1.0 and 2.0 fb −1 of integrated luminosity at 7 and 8 TeV center-ofmass energies in pp collisions, respectively.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Some of the studies exploit a subsample of this set and are under active preparation of updated results.

body_text.text: LHCb detector and software
The LHCb detector [1], Fig.1, is a single-arm forward spectrometer covering the pseudorapidity range 2 < η < 5, specially designed for the study of particles containing b or c quarks.
body_text.section: LHCb detector and software

body_text.text: The detector includes a high precision tracking system, consisting of a silicon-strip vertex detector surrounding the pp interaction region, a largearea silicon-strip detector located upstream of a dipole magnet with a bending power of about 4 Tm, and three stations of silicon-strip detectors and straw drift tubes placed downstream.
body_text.section: LHCb detector and software

body_text.text: The combined tracking system has momentum resolution Δp/p that varies from 0.4% at 5 GeV/c to 0.6% at 100 GeV/c, and impact parameter (IP) resolution of 20 μm for tracks with high transverse momentum.
body_text.section: LHCb detector and software

body_text.text: Charged hadrons are identified using two ring-imaging Cherenkov detectors (RICH) [2].
body_text.section: LHCb detector and software

body_text.text: Photon, electron and hadron candidates are identified by a calorimeter system consisting of scintillating-pad and preshower detectors, an electromagnetic calorimeter and a hadronic calorimeter.
body_text.section: LHCb detector and software

body_text.text: Muons are identified by a system composed of alternating layers of iron and multiwire proportional chambers.
body_text.section: LHCb detector and software

body_text.text: The trigger [3] consists of a hardware stage, based on information from the calorimeter and muon systems, followed by a software stage which applies a full event reconstruction.

body_text.text: Forward physics studies

The complementarity in pseudo-rapidity coverage of the LHCb detector with the ATLAS and CMS detectors has triggered several non-heavy-flavour physics analyses including topics on QCD, electroweak physics, Higgs boson and search for new heavy long-lived particles.
body_text.section: Forward physics studies

body_text.text: Beside first searches such as the search for the decay H 0 → τ + τ − [44], more recent studies include the measurement of the Z + b-jet production cross-section and a search for a hypothetical heavy long-lived particle decaying into a bb pair.
body_text.section: Forward physics studies

body_text.text: For Z + b-jet [45], cross sections in the range 100 − 300 fb have been measured for two b-jet transverse momentum thresholds, p T > 10, 20 GeV/c, with substantial statistical and systematical uncertainties.
body_text.section: Forward physics studies

body_text.text: Within Hidden Valley models [46], some configurations predict the existence of a hypothetical v-pion, π v , produced in neutral Higgs boson decays H → π v π v , and decaying into bb pairs (and other qq decays).
body_text.section: Forward physics studies

body_text.text: A LHCb study [47] has been able to set upper limits on the production cross-section of π v , as a function of its mass and lifetime, as can be seen in Fig. 8.
body_text.section: Forward physics studies

body_text.text: Conclusions

The analysis of Run I data has permitted various improvements in the measurements of CP-violation parameters in B mesons oscillations and decays: the precision on the CKM angles γ and β s from the sole LHCb studies is now below 10 • and 2%, respectively, and is expected to reach less than half these values with Run II data.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: A huge number of observations of new particles, excited states and decays has been published.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The observation of the rare B 0 s → μ + μ − decay is also one of the main achievements.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Hints of discrepancies in observables of the rare B decays have been remarked but are still lacking significance.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: CP violation studies in multibody decays have unveiled complex final state dynamics that still needs to be understood in amplitude analyses.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Forward physics, including the search of Higgsboson and long-lived heavy particles decays, has started to provide first results and might be a corner from where surprises emerge in the future.
body_text.section: Conclusions
